title: How to Make Badam Milk

steps.headline: Soak your almonds for five to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Submerge your almonds in two cups (475 mL) of boiling water. Let your almonds soak for five to 10 minutes. When done, your almonds will appear slightly shriveled. Use a colander to drain the almonds after boiling them.

steps.headline: Peel your almonds.
steps.description: After your almonds are cool to the touch, peel them by hand. Pinch the tip of the almond with between your thumb and forefinger. Then, gently slide the nut out of the skin and set it aside. You can also buy pre-peeled almonds to simplify the process.

steps.headline: Grind the almonds into a paste.
steps.description: Transfer your almonds into a food processor. Grind the almonds in the processor until they form a fine paste. Almonds turn into a powdery, flour-like substance before forming a paste. If you keep grinding, the almonds will eventually form a paste, so just wait it out. Do not add anything to the almonds.

steps.headline: Heat your milk.
steps.description: Place your milk in a saucepan over high heat. Bring the milk to a boil and then reduce the heat to medium.

steps.headline: Add the almond paste to the milk.
steps.description: After the milk boils, pour in the almond paste. Use a spoon to mix the paste slightly so it's evenly incorporated into the milk.

steps.headline: Bring the milk to a boil.
steps.description: Turn the heat back up to high. Keep the heat on high, stirring on occasion, until the mixture boils.

steps.headline: Simmer the almond paste and milk.
steps.description: Reduce the heat to medium to bring the almond paste and milk mixture to a simmer. Let it simmer for 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Mix in the remaining ingredients.
steps.description: Add your saffron, cardamom powder, nutmeg, and sugar to the mixture. Keep the mixture over the heat, stirring it constantly until the sugar dissolves.

steps.headline: Pour the milk into individual glasses to serve.
steps.description: Once the sugar is dissolves, remove your badam milk from the stove. Divide the milk evenly between four glasses.

steps.headline: Garnish the milk with sliced almonds.
steps.description: Add a few sliced almonds to the top of each glass of milk. You can also sprinkle a sweet spice, like cinnamon, on top of the milk.

steps.headline: Refrigerate extra milk.
steps.description: Badam milk should be refrigerated in a sealed container. You can transfer your badam milk to an empty milk carton or a mason jar between servings.

steps.headline: Discard milk once it goes bad.
steps.description: Badam milk can last up to three weeks when stored properly, but some milk goes bad sooner. A sour smell, change in color, and the presence of mold and crust mean the milk has gone bad and should be thrown out.

text: Soaking and Peeling Your Almonds Soak your almonds for five to 10 minutes. Submerge your almonds in two cups (475 mL) of boiling water. Let your almonds soak for five to 10 minutes. When done, your almonds will appear slightly shriveled. Use a colander to drain the almonds after boiling them. Peel your almonds. After your almonds are cool to the touch, peel them by hand. Pinch the tip of the almond with between your thumb and forefinger. Then, gently slide the nut out of the skin and set it aside. You can also buy pre-peeled almonds to simplify the process. Grind the almonds into a paste. Transfer your almonds into a food processor. Grind the almonds in the processor until they form a fine paste. Almonds turn into a powdery, flour-like substance before forming a paste. If you keep grinding, the almonds will eventually form a paste, so just wait it out. Do not add anything to the almonds. Mixing Your Ingredients Heat your milk. Place your milk in a saucepan over high heat. Bring the milk to a boil and then reduce the heat to medium. Add the almond paste to the milk. After the milk boils, pour in the almond paste. Use a spoon to mix the paste slightly so it's evenly incorporated into the milk. Bring the milk to a boil. Turn the heat back up to high. Keep the heat on high, stirring on occasion, until the mixture boils. Simmer the almond paste and milk. Reduce the heat to medium to bring the almond paste and milk mixture to a simmer. Let it simmer for 10 to 15 minutes. Mix in the remaining ingredients. Add your saffron, cardamom powder, nutmeg, and sugar to the mixture. Keep the mixture over the heat, stirring it constantly until the sugar dissolves. Serving Your Badam Milk Pour the milk into individual glasses to serve. Once the sugar is dissolves, remove your badam milk from the stove. Divide the milk evenly between four glasses. Garnish the milk with sliced almonds. Add a few sliced almonds to the top of each glass of milk. You can also sprinkle a sweet spice, like cinnamon, on top of the milk. Refrigerate extra milk. Badam milk should be refrigerated in a sealed container. You can transfer your badam milk to an empty milk carton or a mason jar between servings. Discard milk once it goes bad. Badam milk can last up to three weeks when stored properly, but some milk goes bad sooner. A sour smell, change in color, and the presence of mold and crust mean the milk has gone bad and should be thrown out. Finished.
